Lovely, robust flavors makes Farley's delicious!
Now I'm Farley sure this place could do better.
Awesome place to work from or hangout with friends... They make great coffee too...

This is a really cute neighborhood coffee shop with tables and also a magazine stand in the back (they have a lot of harder to find selections like French Vanity Fair). It's nice to be able to peruse magazines while you wait and sip your coffee.
Unpretentious hipster.

I would give this place 5 stars for atmosphere alone- minimalistic, airy, open space with ample seating and outdoor patio- but I had to take off one star for unfriendly staff and another star for a chin hair (hopefully) found in my $6 fruit and granola yogurt.

I just love coming to this little street in this side of town it's like a little breath of fresh air in the city.  The shops are all so quaint and cute and this coffee shop is no exception. There's a nice feel to this place where I wouldn't mind coming and studying or getting work done. They have board games and a section with magazines to read. My latte was really goood I enjoyed it greatly.
Just havin' one of those days like Monica sings....that a girl goes through :)

Cool coffee shop with good coffee. Grab a seat outside and enjoy the rolling hills and views of SF! Staff were nice; bathroom is old and kinda sketch. Not sure what other yelpers meant by the unfriendliness. I got a smile and conversation as I ordered my drink. People watching is great though on that street. I saw people around me get sandwiches; they looked decent.
Really good coffee and cute area. Has a parklet outside for seating and there's a bunch of magazines inside!

Small indoor space with outdoor seating. I went in on a reasonably busy Sunday, but I was still able to claim a table and a power outlet inside. Chill atmosphere, hipster baristas, good coffee, and free WiFi. Nice place to sit and work-slash-people-watch for hours.
I really want to like this place. The outside patio is nice to sit at, the wifi works, and the area is easy to park in.
neighborhood spot and gathering place. great coffee. nothing not to love, right down to the astroturf sidewalk garden.
Great coffee, great ambiance, and close to the ballpark. Barista very helpful and nice.
I've patronized Farley's regularly for the past year - by regularly I am referring to a visit or two ever 2-3 weeks.   Here's the lowdown:

Nice local spot to meet people. Everyone is casual and friendly. Known for great sandwiches, I stop by for the Ginger Ale. A bookshelf has notebooks that customers fill with artwork, poems, random thoughts ~ and then return to the shelf. Every once in awhile, the place hosts lectures and celebrations for non-profits and the public is welcome. (This is how I discovered the place.) The magazine rack in the corner is like something from a NYC corner back in the day. Friendly staff. Amazing live music once in awhile ... Free parking, which is just about a miracle in SF.

Awesome awesome awesome. Such a cool vibe, friendly baristas, and the coffee is great. They don't mind people camping out with laptops or school books for a few hours, which is so refreshing when many SF coffee shops frown upon it. The music is eclectic and always changing. They have a huge magazine rack where you can buy the magazines or simply read them. Great selection of pastries that always varies.
Solid place with good coffee and other drinks. ALSO ICE CREAM and very good food.
Pretty good coffee shop.   Friendly staff, food was decent.  The outdoor seating is nice.
Slow paced neighborhood coffee house. Read, work on your laptop or kids can use the board games. Very simple, basic, relaxed attitude here.

We waited roughly 20-25 minutes for two lattes.  If that was my only criticism, I'd likely rate this place 4 stars because it's actually quite a nice little cafe.  The 1 star rating is for the terrible service by the girl with pink hair.  Not only did she have a tough time getting the order right (a simple 2 nonfat latte order), but she was incredibly rude about her inability to do so and the resulting wait time.  When I politely asked her to correct the order, she was short with me.  Moreover, we heard her talking to another barista about how "sad" she was for people like us. If I pay 4 dollars for some warm milk and espresso, I expect you to use the right milk.  God forbid you smile.

Dropped by this place first time, there was a long line for the only one register. However the cashier had no problem taking time to chat with the 4 people in front of me for 5 minutes. The coffee was alright, but the milk tastes rancid.
We came in on a Friday afternoon to get some coffee and a light lunch.

A long time hill resident and Farleys' customer, I have finally decided I am done. There are positive things:, the location and the magazine selection. The coffee is no longer to my taste, its now that bitter taste that seems to permeate a lot of coffee shops around the city. But, service and the lack of a good cappuccino are ultimately what drives me away. A cappuccino, is not hot milk, especially if you ask for it specifically foamy. Although some servers are polite and helpful when you complain (nicely, I may add), others let you know of their irritation and still don't seem to know what a cappuccino entails.  Take a lesson from Martha's in efficiency and pleasantness and Philz for the non bitter taste.

Apparently Santa isn't doing Christmas this year because there isn't going to be a taqueria in Potrero Hill.  Lingba is shutting down, and they were the ones behind this new place.  I'm depressed.  No amount of egg nog is going to make up for this one.
I will have to agree with Kim S. here and say that a late-night taqueria on 18th St will be one of wildest dreams come true. Pedro must have won the election!
This place was awesome got a sandwhich with a lot of meat for 5.00
Food is okay but he turns the refrigerators off on the weekend things are not properly chill

Popped in twice. First was the Chicken Salad sammich and the next time was the BLT. I asked for a fresh BLT and didnt want the one made an hour ago sitting on the counter wrapped and ready to go. Dude was like "its gonna take 5 mins". Well then ill wait 5 mins, LOL! He looked hella pissed but at the end was back to his little ol' self thanking my money!

I finally decided to give it a shot after reading previous review. I too got an avocado sammich. It was good enough, but my one complaint I got is this: quoted price was $4.75 but when I got ready to pay, the price became $5.25. I hate surprises and wish they would just state the price after taxes already. It makes me feel deceived if I can't see the price advertised.

My friend and I went into this place after running out of places to get vegan lunch in the area. My friend was asked "What girl is that for?" while his avocado sandwich was made. He ran with it and it was a running thing for a few weeks. Now we have a vegan Korean noodle dish prepared specially for us every Thursday.

This place is whack.  I got a Chicago style dog for $5.  Sesame seed roll. Bun to dog ratio was way off.  no celery salt.  relish was yellow.  sport peppers were round and fat.  Never come here for a Chicago style hot dog.  $5??? you must be out of your mind.
What's Up Dog is literally in a shack on the corner of a street. Service during lunch is fast and friendly.

What's there to be said about What's Up Dog?  Well, they're a booth (and when I say booth, I almost really mean a shack) on the corner of De Haro and 16th that serves up some pretty decent wieners on buns.
Separate the real from the fake. Support Top Dog in Berkeley, don't eat at this imitator.

My boyfriend is an old-fashioned American boy who loves burgers and hot dogs. When he discovered this place just a few blocks from our apartment, he was ecstatic. Unfortunately, they're only open until 5pm on weeknights and he works late so there was no way he could make it there after work. After one failed attempt to have lunch here on a Sunday (they say they're open if weather permits but they were closed despite the fact that it was sunny and beautiful), we finally managed to stop by here last Saturday.
I had a craving for a chili dog this morning, so I found this place on Yelp. The reviews looked pretty good, so I went for it.

I've been wanting to try their veggie dog so I finally did yesterday. I was kind of disappointed they only had only two options for veggieheads. I chose the veggie chicago style dog and added 1.75 for a combo with drink and chips. I noticed they only had three types of lay chips which were original, bbq, and sour cream and onion. I chose sour cream and onion and for my drink, a can of lemon iced tea. When I got my hot dog, it had mustard,onions,pickles,tomatoes, and peppercinis. Not a big fan for fresh onions but I gave it a try.The hot dog was pretty good and filling. Probably give their other locations a try just for their appetizers and veggie burger.
This is about what I'd expect out of a street corner hot dog stand. Nothing fancy, no exceptional service, just hot dogs, and decent ones at that.

i try not to think about what's in a hot dog so it's not often i have these puppies.  but when friends suggested this place while we were at the IndieMart around the corder, i contemplated for nearly 10 minutes if i should order one or two.  i finally made up my mind NOT to share and ordered the chicago style dog with sport peppers AND jalapenos. um.... now i love my spicy but even this was a bit intense for me (but the burn hurt so good). they don't have the complete menu at this little stand that serves up only dogs at this particular location. the dogs themselves are a bit on a skinny side, IMO, but i also was a gluttonous fat man in another life. next time i'll likely try the chili cheese dog... more meat, pls! also, you can't beat the price of under $5.

Great hotdogs at a reasonable price.  This place is 2 blocks away from my office so I go here all the time.  So yummy!  They keep office hours so it's not open early or for dinner, but lunch time is what's up.

First off I have no complaints about the actual dogs or sausages. BUT, if you are going to claim you have a Chicago Style Dog then learn how to do it correctly. First off a Sport Pepper. Thay are little skinny dark green peppers. Not the bulbous yellow ones What's Up uses. Secondly the "Pickle Spears", and I use the term SPEAR loosely, as the obviously bottled, vinegar sour pickles (Vlasic??) are NOT the Koshe Dill Spear (crisp and stiff) that should be on a proper Chicago dog. Thirdly, the tomatoes. NOT chopped, but a thin slice of the whole tomatoe, a circle, draped across the completed dog, THEN the celery salt gets sprinkled. Fourth, the sausage or dog itself.  POSITION it in the bun correctly. The ends should curve up, this way the toppings have a depression to nestle in so they don't fall all over your lap when you take a bite. I was going to give What's Up a 3 star but after reading my own review 2 is all they deserve. They do have potential, but until then? Go to Da Beef when they are open or The grill on Folsom (they both have Italian Beef also!)
What's up dog has a kiosk in the corner of this mini shopping center.

This location has a limited menu compared to the Beale Street location but it offers my favorites in the Chicago Style Hot Dog and the Polish. Their service has been fast every time I have visited and their dogs are very good. Recommended.
I just want to know, what are the hours of business? Grazie!
This blue hot dog stand gets extra points for being the cutest food stand in the chain.

Sweet little shack for a dog or two.  I usually stick with the lemon chicken or the chicken apple sausage...or both, depending how loud my stomach is growling...sans bun(s) of course (thank you gluten allergy).

The standard two-star descriptor is, "Meh. I've experienced better."  As in, much better at other What's Up Dog locations.  At the other locations, you get freshly grilled (or at least, freshly regrilled) dogs and also fresh made corndogs (Yum).  Not at the DE HARO location.  The dog was pulled from a metal container, I can't verify, but I think it might have even been sitting in hot water.  Not my favorite.  And the bun wasn't toasted as I like it, on the grill.  I can appreciate that the space is super small, but unless there's a fire code violation, they should stick an electric grill in there and fire it up!

I tried the Chicago Dog yesterday and liked it so much, I came back for another one today. Yes, I still think $4.50 is too much for a hot dog but this Chicago Dog is pretty tasty. Piled high with tomatoes, diced onions, relish, a pickle spear and peppers, slathered with mustard, and sprinkled with a light coat of celery salt, this is one delicious hot dog. The best part is feeling  the "snap' of the hot dog as you sink your teeth into it and all those toppings blend together like a midwest party in your mouth. Awesome!
Fast and no frills.

This place is alllright...so to break it down there is a guy in a box making food...yes it's a box and I almost felt sorry that he had to chill there by himself in an area that was 3x3 feet. The sink is about a foot away from the other side and food so that didn't make me feel any better about the whole thing, then i went and ordered the wrong thing. I ordered NACHOS from a hot dog stand. I should be ridiculed on sight for doing something so retarded. They didn't taste good, the cheese was not melted, and the chii was subpar. My friend ordered some dogs and they seemed not bad. Then again I would prefer the good ol mission bacon wrapped hot dogs instead...

I walked by this place several times.  It is a tiny hot dog stand located on corner of a street.  The menu is short.. The prices are very reasonable.  I think it is around 3 dollars and up.  There is nothing fancy about the hot dogs.  No "gourmet" hot dogs with weird and exotic ingredients (e.g., Trader Joe's).  They have the standard lineup of hot dogs.  That is, frankfurters, hot links, and polish dogs.  They have the typical condiments, such as ketchup, mustard, french mustard, sour kraut, chopped onions and relish.

This humble stand is a block away from my workplace, so I check it out pretty often. Sometimes you just get that craving for a dog. The guys who work there are cool, and the menu is quite diverse for a small stand. There's also a new special every week or so like different kinds of bratwurst. Best of all, pretty much everything is under five bucks. Not quite Costco cheap, but really, who can top Costco?
I visit this stand about once a month... and I have tried all the dogs in the cart... It's good to talk to the guy who man's the stand as he owns his spot.
I remember driving past the one in the Financial District every other day dropping an ex off to work. I would cornily say "what's up dawg!" every time we passed.

I wanted to get a hotdog at around 2 PM.  They were out, and even though I was happy to wait, the two guys inside really didn't feel like putting new ones in right now (wanted to take a smoke break on the side) and tried very hard to convince me to get a polish sausage instead. Fine, I'll try it. With sauerkraut.
Mmmmmm... hot dogs... my mouth is watering just thinking about one...

"WHAT'S UP DOG!" The branding is genius! So my girlfriend and I decided to stop by since the name was so catchy and we had heard so much about it . We wanted to see if the dogs were as good as their name. We stopped by and were greeted by a very nice guy. I ended up getting the Chicago loaded with toppings....tasty! My girlfriend ended up getting the Tomato Basil Turkey...for you health-conscious ladies out there...a guilt free 200 calories! THAT was so good I ended eating half of it (it was huge). On top of that, there were a few benches outside where you can sit and enjoy which you don't find at hot dog stands. Great experience!!!

Dog was standard, out of a package, already made, toppings extra. Service got them the fourth star. I asked if the special of the week, a tomato basil dog was lowfat, and the guy working the booth offered to show me the nutritional content of every one I was interested in (healthy yelper tip - lemon chicken is the healthiest at 200 calories and 12 grams of fat).

I've been on a hot dog kick lately.  I dunno maybe its the weather.  And when I gets my hot dog on, I don't F around, I go big.  Chili dog with jalapenos and sport peppers.  It was pretty good, didn't blow my mind, however this spot is conviniently located just far enough from the office that you can chill on the bench next to the stand for an extended lunch.  Ill be baaaaack!
I tried the sun-dried tomato And basil and it was deelish! I give this place a 5 star I just feel bad for the poor dude that has to work there!

I had a Chili Cheese Dog. It was DELICIOUS! and Chili Cheese Nachos too.....*drool*.....It's so close by my work, I'll be going there often. It's a tiny little shack in a parking lot. I don't know how that guy can stand being in there all day. I'd get claustrophobic!
I have just recently gotten into hot dogs and I couldn't have been happier to see the stand on the corner of deharo and 16th open up (right in front of Sally's).
My husband has eaten lunch here almost every day since this tiny kiosk opened on De Haro.

Great Dogs! My partner and I had Polish Dogs and Hot links...both were tasty and fresh. And all the condiments were very fresh and handy right there in the front of the building. Everything is priced really well and we felt we got a great lunch for only 10 bucks. This place is only a week old and is a great add to our neighborhood! We love it!

Brand new location. The guys running it were really nice. Prices are great. I got a chili dog and a hot link (had to try a variety). The chili dog was tastey, add some onions (nice fresh cut) and the chili was good. Bun was soft not stale even though it was later in the day. The hot link was good, spicey but not overwhelling. condiments were all fresh. Terrible pun good dog!

We were really disappointed with Bistro 350. Nothing we ordered was particularly good, and my duck was actually inedible. They do have fun cocktail specials (raspberry vodka lemonade when we were there), and the desserts (which are actually pretty decent) are only $3.50. I guess I would recommend it for coffee and dessert.

I'm wavering between two and three stars here. It would be two if this were a full-fledged restaurant, except that I can't judge them too harshly because this IS a school, and we should've known what we were in for from the get-go.
Not as bad as you think.

Nice open dining room, waitstaff was very helpful if a little slow at times (everyone's learning! I know how that feels) the food is without a doubt better than the CCA's offerings on Polk street and the dining room is much nicer as well. For some reason they had on a Frank Sinatra album that seemed to be playing just a little bit too fast which made my dining companion start to twich uncontrollably by the end of the meal. Mushroom tart was stellar, my friend's lamb shank was huge and nicely cooked, my duck 'three ways' was a little tough in one iteration, a little cold in the second and not identifyable as duck in the third. But like the other reviewers say, hit or miss. A nice addition to the Potrero Hill dead zone on 16th Street.

this is the potrero hill campus restaurant of the California Culinary Academy.  on a thursday night, we were one of only 3 parties dining there....which was a little sad considering the place probably holds close to 100 or so guests but it is a very nice open space.  nice atmosphere.  great presentation of the food.  modern and funky and artsy.   too bad the food isn't as spectactular.  but it is being prepared by culinary students after all so don't expect michael mina.

Hit or miss.  It's in the Culinary Academy so the kitchen staff and the waitstaff are all students, perfecting their art.  On good days you can get some awesome food (rabbit, bass, salmon, veal, steak, crab, vegan soup, mushroom tarts, etc) for supercheap prices.  On bad days you might get something spilled on you and have to send your steak back to be cooked longer.  For the adventurous one who want expensive food for not so expensive prices.  you just might be pleasantly surprised.  (ps. they have limited hours since it's a school...lunch 11:30-1, dinner 6-8)
